description:
Sir Wayne, thank you for greeting us was we walked in. You have such a cool vibe and you made us feel at home here!
I thought this was a bar when I walked in a week ago. To my surprise, you sell pierogis! And not just any pierogis...amazingly STUFFED ones!!!! Foodies pierogis!!! Glad you're on my neighborhood!! Will be back soon. And again!

Had he mushroom, jalapeño and goat cheese varieties. Can't wait to try more!
author: Larry G.

description:
Tried the 5 pierogi deal. 

Food: 2/5. Some of the perogies were super soggy. Bland flavors. Something was missing. 

But take my review with a grain of salt. 
I haven't had perogis before.
author: J P.

description:
Okay this place is pretty cool. It's like a divey restaurant if that's a thing so don't come here expecting a nice ambiance because you're not gonna get that. This is a no frills sort of establishment where the main seating is bar seating, so come in with an open mindset. :)

Stuffed is a one man show churning out pirogies and polish sides. I have learned that they used to make the pirogies fresh and on the spot but it looks like now they make them in the morning, store them in a warmer, and then pan fry them as they are ordered. 

The food is pretty cheap I'd say! Each one is $4 or you could get the meal sizes (2,3, or 4 pirogies with 2 sides for $10, $14, $17 respectively) and they are hearty sized and filling!

I decided to get the 2 pirogies and 2 sides deal for $10 and chose borscht (a polish soup) and cucumber salad for my sides. The borscht was really good and the two friends I was with agreed! It was light and heartwarming, with large notes of dill). For my pirogies I ordered the jalapeño and the spinach & feta I believe. They were SO good - really filling from the potato and flavorful, with sautéed onions on top, adding a nice touch. They also were nice and crispy from the pan sear. The jalapeño one definitely had a nice kick! I'll be back to try the mushroom one and the avocado one as those were sold out. 

Subtracting one star for service. One of my friends didn't get the borscht she ordered until we reminded them and both had to remind about the beers they had ordered. Overall though, I'd recommend Stuffed as a simple spot to grab some hearty Polish grub at a good price point!
author: Sabina S.

description: Looking for a dive bar with some killer grub close to public transportation? Here you go. Yum yum yum.
author: eryn y.

description:
This place is excellent for a late night snack. Unfortunately, the new guy that works there always seems to be in a bad mood and it makes me want to walk the other way, back out the door. Not sure if he doesn't like people or if he just doesn't want to be there. 

The lady that worked there before was so nice and friendly. She had her Dad's home made wines on the menu, which were excellent!

The food is delicious and comforting. The service leaves something to be desired.
author: Joaquin C.

description:
So I realized it's been two years since I reviewed and I still LOVE Stuffed! Dana the owner and Dwayne are gracious, lovely people. When you are in the space, you feel like you are with family. 

For a short time there was this sandwich pop-up in the space during the day and I thought it was a great idea but the sandwiches were terrible; too little ingredients and over priced for what you got...it didn't help that they were served by a surly, not too friendly woman. I am glad Stuffed is back to doing what they do best; serving up delicious perogies in a chill spot! 

By the way, perogies are NEVER made on the spot, anywhere...it is a labor intensive project; you have to make the dough, then you put in the filling and boil. After these steps you then can either freeze for later use or fry in butter for immediate satisfaction.
author: Annie K.

description: I showed up on Sunday at 1:30pm and Stuffed was in the dark. Even the electronic sign on the door for showing the hours was out of service. I am guessing this restaurant might not be in business anymore? Too bad I was really looking forward to it.
author: Grace H.

description: Love Love Love Love this place! Pierogi's are amazing and the sides are all amazing! I don't like sauerkraut but their apple sauerkraut is amazing. Wayne, one of the owners, is amazing!!!!
author: Sherria T.

description: I've tried practically the entire menu now and it's never disappointing. Don't sleep on this spot. Swing the extra 5$, try the polish sausage and for the two included sides do the purple slaw and polish style cucumber salad.  Order any pierogi you're feeling. It's all fire.
author: Stephen M.

description: Amazing food I loved all of it and the atmosphere. I really liked the fact I could pay with cryptocurrency #FatHa
author: Dillon L.

description:
I typically hate when people leave bad reviews without eating the food, but this place is a real shit show. I should've known better when I tried to place an order through their website, but the restaurant wouldn't show up on Eat24 even though I was through their own link. I wanted  to use a website because the menu online wasn't the same as the recent yelp pictures, and I didn't want to have them describe the differences over the phone if possible. I was able to place an order with grubhub so I went with it. 

I was even notified that they are making my order. When I got to the restaurant, the one guy there said he didn't receive any order. Even after showing my order he didn't care at all. He didn't try to make sure on the computer or anything. He said he can make the food, but I would have to pay again. I only brought my ID so that wouldn't work. I just walked out. 

I can't speak for the food, but whoever is running it his place needs to take a good look under the hood. I know I won't be coming back.
author: Jo B.

description: So, is Stuffed still open? We showed up looking forward to some polish food Saturday at 6:30 pm and Stuffed looked shut down. Very disappointed since Yelp said that it was was open and we journeyed over on BART from Berkeley.
author: Chris B.

description:
I came in here randomly at 11 pm on a Saturday night because the line at Farolito was too long with obnoxious drunk people in it. I had no idea what to expect. I got the potato spinach perogi and the chicken potato feta perogi. They were so shockingly delicious, I was almost in disbelief that this place existed.

The Polish-style cucumber salad was on point, although I didn't care for the oily lukewarm borscht.

Will definitely come back to try more perogis!
author: Eve P.

description: Perogis and borscht were kind of meh. The cucumber salad was great. Prices are cheap though.
author: Billy D.

description: I am Polish. And I spent the first 20 years of my life eating pierogis regularly. My grandma used to make them, my mom used to make them, my aunts used to make them etc.. We would eat them at least once every 2 weeks and they were always served for Christmas, weddings and all the important celebrations. You get the picture. I know what pierogis are. Stuffed pierogis don't really remind me of pierogis I grew up with. They are giant, tough and fried while Polish pierogis are always boiled and only if there are leftovers you may fry them the next day. I went to Stuffed 3 times over the past 2 years. The first time I thought that the food was decent and inexpensive. The second time is was passable but disappointing. The third time I knew I would never go back. The place is depressing, has the abandoned feeling to it and the food is not appetizing. Look at the very color of their borsch. It doesn't look like borsch and it doesn't taste like borsch. The pierogis' dough is tough and the stuffing combinations weird. The place doesn't feel Polish at all... It just feels like someone's afterthought. Maybe someone started it with good intentions but got bored quickly enough and moved on to better things. This place has no Polish spirit and its food doesn't give justice to Polish national cuisine, which, while executed properly, can be addictive and memorable.
author: ania w.

description: The pierogis and kielbasa were so good! I highly recommend the bacon and cheese pierogi. And the owner was so nice and pleasant to talk to. Can't believe it took me this long to finally try this place, but I'm glad I did and I will def be coming back more often.
author: Mercedes N.

description:
Meh. I prefer my pierogis to be a bit more browned. These were served a bit mushy.

A couple friends and I went there at around 6pm on a Saturday - we were the first customers of the day.  We were there all by ourselves until about 7pm when a few others arrived.

There was only one guy working the counter, nice enough - he was the whole show, order taker, drink server, cashier, AND cook.

We all ordered the 3 pierogi platter (comes with 2 sides) - and we got a polish sausage to share (which was the highlight). I ordered the mushroom, the jets, and the potato bacon and cheese (which was my favorite of the 3).  It comes with 2 sides - I got the cucumber salad, and the apple/sauerkraut. The krout tasted like canned, the cucumber salad was unremarkable.

Another one I am glad I knocked off the list, but I was not overly impressed.
author: Amy W.

description: These are the best pierogies I've ever had, very open-minded place suitable for the younger or the older crowd. The owner also accepts cryptocurrency so clearly she is up to date with all the cool new technologies.
author: Mike S.

description: Dwayne is a one man show with these pierogis! Faves were the traditional, mushroom, bacon cheddar and blueberry. Wow. Simple and good. The homemade wine is delish too. Tak!!
author: C P.

description:
If you haven't checked out Stuffed, you are missing out!!!!  The classic Polish food is absolutely DELICIOUS, the service is friendly and prompt, and the prices are very affordable!

I've been here a handful of times.  The first time for a friend's birthday party, where 16 of us scrunched in together around the outdoor table on their front patio.  We ordered communally, one or two of everything on the menu, and shared...this was a great idea, a wonderful way to get to try everything without too much commitment!!  Each order of five Pierogies came with a sweet, finely chopped purple Cabbage Slaw, sauteed onions atop the Pierogies, Sour Cream to eat them with, and either Cucumber Salad or Borscht (also served traditionally with sour cream on top!), both of which were equally delectable! 

While all the options were delicious, my absolute favorites were the Bacon Cheddar, Goat Cheese Spinach, and the mesmerizingly delicious Sweet Potato Perogis!!!

I've been here several times since, and each time I leave feeling happy...and super-Stuffed!!!

I HIGHLY recommend this woefully-underappreciated restaurant!!!
author: Amy L.

description: I feel like this place has so much potential but it's poorly managed. Went there on a Tuesday night and the it was empty, I still decided to give it a try. Music was out of control blasting (no one needs that while trying to enjoy a meal... prices were great , and food is quite tasty , soup was too oily. I'll definitely give it another try
author: Eva S.

description:
FOOD: pierogi meals (traditional and fusion, like goat cheese) are filling and flavorful. That said, the pierogi texture and size I find to be far from traditional. The pierogi are huge (think Costco-size ravioli). 

Don't get me wrong--the food is solid. I am only disappointed because the quality of my first visit two years ago--where I met the owners who showed the the pierogi cutting tools and where the salad portions were much more generous--was superb. Since then, my pierogis have been too overstuffed for my liking and a little gummy after being over-boiled. 

SERVICE: friendly enough. Again, two years ago the founders were much more personable. I usually am met by a worker now who is polite and attentive enough, but not as smiley and welcoming :). 

AMBIANCE: cozy but never loud! There is outdoor seating as well, and though right by 24th BART, a little shielded from the street by some succulent planters! 

I've been several times, so obviously it hits the spot!
author: Helen W.

description:
Stuffed is what happens when a Russian guy inherits a bar and wants to stay true to his roots while appealing to the hipster clientele of the Mission- at least that's my take on this place.

Grabbed the 5 piece mix and match pierogi plate ($20) to share with a friend:
TRADITIONAL (tasty, thick skin, perfect with fried onions and sour cream)
BUFFALO & BLEU CHEESE (bar food as a dumpling, the only one that worked)
SPINACH & GOAT CHEESE (oddly didn't have much flavor)
SPINACH DOUGH & MUSHROOM (vegan-friendly? dough didn't hold up)
AVOCADO & SAUSAGE (spicy, mushy mess, didn't even seem to be a pierogi)
SIDES: Borscht was bland as if made to appeal to people who have never had it, apple-cabbage slaw was crunchy and refreshing but neither of us cared for it.

Staff were friendly, bar itself is cozy- wish I had noticed the shuffleboard table in the back before it was time for us to leave. Good place to watch a game.
author: Stefany V.

description:
Delicious perogies, great dive bar atmosphere, good homemade wine. All affordable -- $3/perogie, and it would probably take 3 or 4 to fill you up completely.

I'd highly recommend this place for a lower-key night out (or to start/end a more exciting night).
author: Valerie P.

description: I was here a few years ago and I think back then they used to actually prepare all the food there and it was absolutely delicious. I came back last night (Thursday night) and the food was pre-made and there was one guy serving and he just reheated the food. No one was there and it was just sad. The food was ok, nothing to write home about and it definitely was much less tasty than it used to be. This place just went really downhill and it's pretty sad. It used to be really good.
author: Irina I.

description:
Stumbled upon this place during a vacation in San Fran. Being from Cleveland I was a bit skeptical that a San Fran pierogi joint would be legit. I was wrong. VERY wrong.

The location is no frills and the bartender was actually the owner of the establishment... she was extremely nice and welcoming and after a few Great Lakes beers we found out she was a Cleveland transplant with polish roots. The pierogis were absolutely out-of-this-world delicious. I cannot rave about this place enough and can't wait for my next trip to San Fran to check this place out once again. Definitely a must-try if you are in the Mission!
author: Doug E.

description:
Color me oblivious. It's a hue between magenta and moronic. I'm sure I've walked by this place over a dozen times in the past year it's been open, but I didn't take notice until it showed up on my Yelp app when I was looking for a late-ish dinner after work. I scratched my head since the address looked like it was on the same block as El Farolito next to the 24th Street BART station. Sure enough, it's right across the street in between two discount stores. It's a narrow space with a long counter and tables out in a sheltered patio (photo: http://bit.ly/1ryVbi5). There not a single soul in the place, not even the owner, but the minute I looked down at the menu, he came out of the darkness to take my order.

I know what pierogis are - dumpling aficionado that I am - but I needed a refresher from the owner, especially how they make them. These are not the potato-cheese creations that you would expect to buy in a Krakow deli. No, these reflect the owners' Midwestern background as they are bigger and carry a broader variety of fillings like smoked salmon, bacon cheddar, goat cheese and spicy avocado sausage. I decided to take advantage of the $13 Two-Pierogi and Whole Sausage Meal with Mushroom and Jalapeño my two selections (photo: http://bit.ly/1zPFRR0). It was quite a plateful of food as it also included Sweet Purple Cabbage Slaw, Apple Sauerkraut and Cucumber Salad.

It was delicious comfort food especially with the caramelized onions strewn about, the split pork sausage juicy and spicy and a dollop of sour cream as a finishing touch (photo: http://bit.ly/1HZNW54). I think I'd like to come back and try some of their dessert pierogis since those are filled with ricotta and cream cheese and fresh berries. I did chat a bit with co-owner Andrew Schoengrund since I was rather concerned the place was completely empty all the time I was there. He assured me weekends are busy when there's a game on. That's when I realized that this was not targeted to those looking for a full-fledged dining experience. Rather it's a destination for weekend warriors and club-hoppers looking for a quick bite. Sounds good to me.

FOOD - 4 stars...quite tasty pierogis & sausage served up home style with lots of sides
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...not all that conducive for dining but a quick bite works
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...appears to run the place by himself when it's slow
TOTAL - 4 stars...more dumplings for me, please
author: Ed U.

description: The food was good! I like it but the service was not good. Maybe the waiter was in the bad mood.
author: Pinarat S.

description:
Being originally from Poland, I wanted to give this place a try and see how it would compare to some of the food I used to have as a kid. The bottom line is that the pierogi were decent, but I had a few issues with the place.

We had four different kinds. The original (potatoes and cheese) were quite good and fairly close to what they should taste like. Those were served with onions and sour cream and had a nice soft texture. The cheddar and bacon pretty much tasted like what you would imagine, with the bacon flavor dominating. Those came with sour cream as well. Jalapeno pierogi were green in color, with a filling that was similar to potatoes and cheese, but had some fresh jalapenos blended in. Spicy and pretty good, but nothing traditional anymore in terms of Eastern European food. Finally, the blueberry pierogi were a good choice for desert and were served with a sweet mascarpone type of topping. One person commented that they tasted like the blueberry and dough did not go well together, which was a good point, but did not bother me. They were not too sweet.

On top of that, the Polish sausage was disappointing as it tasted more like a big hot dog than a real Polish sausage. The red beet soup (borscht) was pretty good and had pieces of shredded beet and some sour cream to lighten it blended in. A lot of the fresh salads that came as sides like red cabbage or cucumber were just ok.

I had an excellent lemon ginger beer, I think it was a Radler, which I've never had before. It was surprisingly good. However, this brings me to the negatives. After a few minutes I noticed a fly floating around in my beer. Then I noticed several other ones flying around us. The place itself could use some decor and it looked like it could be bit cleaner.

I would recommend Russian Renaissance on Geary instead for inexpensive Eastern European food.
author: Tim Z.

description: This place is a cool local place but the service is appalling. The food is simple Polish bar food and is pretty nice. I like the vibe here. It's a cool place. But the service is terrible and feels like an effort for whoever is behind the bar. And that person does everything: takes orders, pours beers, cooks, serves, and fixes the check. They are usually too busy or don't seem to care which is a shame. This place could be great if you got the feeling they wanted you there....
author: Chris D.

description:
Happy happy happy happy happy. I LOVE STUFFED! 

This place has been bookmarked on my list for SO LONG. The only pierogi I can find in the Bay Area you say? I just have a hard enough time getting out of the East Bay in general, let alone to the mission but when we and le fiance scheduled an SF date, I knew this had to be our dinner spot. 

I am Polish and love Polish food - I also make my own homemade pierogi so lets just say I'm pretty picky. This place truly delivered. I loved the trendy take the place did on pierogi fillings - you could get anything from goat cheese and spinach to bacon and cheddar. The jalapeno and bacon and cheddar were my favorites - goat cheese was close second. The salmon tasted a little funny to me - pierogi in my head should be meaty not fishy - but if you're into salmon I'm sure it could be your thing. My only suggestion to the management is that maybe you could think of doing pan fried pierogi options too? That's how I make mine and it just doubles the level of comfort food-ness. I also wish they had pierogi z ruskie because it's my favorite - but I've heard they have that at other times. 

Le fiance and I split a pitcher of pilsener for $15. All in all, we spent about $17 each for a full plate of Polish food and 2.5 beers. Not bad at all! I wish there was one closer!!!  

Na zdrowie!!!
author: Courtney C.

description: Very authentic Polish dumplings and sides! Dumplings are served fresh and hot, very big in size. Sides are all tasty. Blueberry Pierogi is my favorite. You never get this great specialty from any stores in the US that sells Polish food.
author: Jasmine W.

description: Stuffed is a themed Polish restaurant in the mission. The theme is PIEROGIES! I was weirdly excited to dine at such a restaurant, expecting something in line with the spots in the east village of NYC that highlight such types of food. It wasn't quite the same. What they did have is a shitload of different kinds of homemade pierogies. What the pierogies lacked was the right ratio of shell to filling. They were kind of all over the place, with some having huge puffy casings and others with really mushy shells. I'm not sure if this was intentional to go with the contents of the pierogi or we just happened to be eating there on the day that 5 different dudes were in the back making completely different pierogi shells. At any rate, the one dude we saw who was working there was nice. The place was completely empty at 6pm on a Monday for whatever that's worth. It didn't take too long to get the food, but it wasn't like the ambiance was that amazing either. We sat outside so we had full view of/interaction with the local street people. Pretty sure I saw someone urinate on a bush while we ate but that doesn't seem to be that uncommon around that particular area.
author: Kaia V.

description:
Pierogies are great, super authentic! They're HUGE and super flavorful, crispy outside and delicious filling with a side of sautéed onions and coleslaw. They have a lot of different types, I'd recommend getting a bunch and splitting it with you friends you can try everything! Low-key restaurant with a few tables - although if you're a big group you can hog the big table at the end.

Only detraction is that they take a somewhat long time to bring out the food. It doesn't really matter though, cause you can play shuffleboard while you wait!

Did I mention shuffleboard? Ask the bartender or someone around to teach you how to play. At first I stereotyped it as an "old person game" but it's actually really, really fun and requires a lot of skill!

Super convenient location next to 24th St. station, great place to wait for someone coming off the BART and kill some time with drinks and shuffleboard!
author: Victor S.

description:
Pierogis were good but the really yummy sauces and sides made it for me.  Sweet slaw, where have you been my whole life?

We got the 5-pierogi plate:  Buffalo, Jalapeno, Bacon Cheddar, Salmon and Blueberry (dessert).  It came with sides of apple sauerkraut, bell pepper salad and the to-die-for sweet slaw.

The Blueberry Dessert one was a bit too heavy (I would've preferred fresh cream to the heavy cannoli-style sour cream), but still found it yummy by the end.

I'm deducting one star because the pierogis took a long time to come even though we were the only customers in the entire store.  At least they were fried fresh I suppose, but it was 9pm and we were starving.
author: Letitia L.

description: Highly recommend this place. Staff is friendly and they accept Ethereum along with other cryptocurrencies! The food is delicious and the vibes are great. Definitely stop by!
author: Tarick R.

description:
I haven't written anything in awhile and with an extra day off of work I decided I had to write some stuff.  So what better stuff to write about than the great stuff they serve at Stuffed!

Stuffed located on Mission Street near 24th Street serves up freshly made pierogies and other Polish inspired specialties.  I had them bookmarked on Yelp seemingly forever when I finally tried them last month.  I loved their food so much that I returned for more this weekend.  For those of you not in the know a pierogi is a dumpling usually boiled then either baked or fried consisting of a filling of mashed potatoes, meat and or vegetables.

My first encounter with the pierogi came many years ago in possibly the last place you'd expect.  Sold under the brand name "Mrs. T's" the little potato and cheese dumplings were boiled up and served to event participants at the finish line of the world famous Escape from Alcatraz Triathlon.  Served with a bit of marinara sauce and a dusting of parmesan cheese those little dumplings became a staple of mine in training for various races in which I took part in.  Finding the brand in my supermarket freezer became a bit of a chore though, and I eventually gave up looking and returned to more common pasta dishes for my carbo-loading and training ways.

It had been at least 10 years since I've had a real pierogi so I was excited.  I ordered the 2 pierogi meal with a jalapeno pierogi and a bacon cheddar one (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/stuffed-san-francisco?select=FylvFlTVxWKZUqAhkKjDqg#QPaRawibu3D0ot_IG1rU5Q).  The pierogies come with a sweet red cabbage slaw and a very different and very delicious sauerkraut which incorporates apples and caraway seeds all sweetened with a bit of agave.  I got to choose between a creamy cucumber salad or a cold asparagus salad for which I chose the latter.  Everything on the plate blew me away.  I especially liked how the dumpling dough for the jalapeno pierogi was infused with jalapeno.  That was my favorite of the two.

This past weekend I happened to be in the neighborhood again for the Carnaval San Francisco parade, and after standing under the hot sun for 6 hours of Carnaval fun I immediately thought of Stuffed for a cold beer and more delicious pierogies.  Going with the theme for the day I ordered an icy cold Corona with lime and a 2 pierogi meal with the smoked salmon pierogi and the spicy avocado sausage pierogi (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/stuffed-san-francisco?select=FylvFlTVxWKZUqAhkKjDqg#FylvFlTVxWKZUqAhkKjDqg).  My salad choice for the day was the bell pepper broccoli salad.  Once again I enjoyed everything on the plate but I found I liked the spicy avocado pierogi with its smooth potato and avocado puree and chunks of sausage even more than the jalapeno one.

Stuffed offers delicious pierogies in many varieties including a blueberry dessert one that is served only during the dinner hours.  They also began pickling their own vegetables just a few weeks ago.  With cool bar style seating and an assortment of cold beers offered I imagine I'll be eating here more often.

If only Stuffed weren't open on weekdays at the exact same hours that I'm at my job.  That's okay though.  They're opened all day on weekends and that gives me more delicious pierogi stuff to look forward to.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description: This was my first pierogi. It's kind of a greasy slippery thing that I did not expect, but it tastes pretty good and the service was good too
author: Mila K.

description: These taste like exactly what they say they have in them. Exactly like the ingredients listed! Now whether or not that's a good thing is up for debate. They're definitely on the weird side. Other than that, good customer service, and the price is not that bad but I wouldn't call it cheap.
author: Raquel R.

description:
Solid food. Cool place to hang and very nice owners. My biggest complaint is the lack of Midwestern beer that was promised.

I even helped crowd fund this place. Mostly because it seemed there would be Midwestern beer offered. Miller and PBR don't count.
author: Ben H.

description:
Wow, I can't believe this place has such a high rating.

We got the 5 pierogi plate plus a polish sausage. Sausage came out first on its own plate & tasted like a run-of-the-mill grocery store sausage. Also there was a hair on the plate. Yuck.
Pierogis came out a few minutes later. The traditional was soggy & flavorless, the mushroom was also soggy & flavorless, and the avocado was so-so. The bacon-cheddar and blue cheese were decent but probably just because they had some actual flavor. Won't be back.
author: C M.

description:
I've been meaning to give Stuffed a try for awhile.  Finally, one Friday night we were driving around the Mission and low and behold there was a parking space right in front.  It was meant to be.  I took it as a sign.  We quickly ordered a couple of their pierogis.  Once we ordered we were told we could sit anywhere which we did.  They have a couple of board games available if you wanted to play which is kinda nice.  There were only 2 people working that night.  One being the waiter/cashier and the other being the cook/dishwasher.  It wasn't very crowded...just a couple of 2 people parties other than ourselves.  The waiter was pretty friendly despite forgetting to give us water, utensils, and the drinks we ordered.  

We ordered the mushroom and cheese, bacon and cheddar, spicy sausage and avocado, and traditional pierogis with the strawberry pierogi for dessert.  The dishes came with purple slaw, apple sauerkraut, and a brussel sprout salad which were all interestingly flavored.  In my opinion, the best pierogi was the bacon and cheddar.  It definitely had the most flavor other than the strawberry dessert pierogi.  In my opinion, the other pierogis lacked flavor and were very heavy.
author: Christine D.

description:
Stuffed indeed. Reasonable price and excellent location.

From the pictures, it looked like a much bigger shop but it turns out to be rather tiny. They have a few tables outdoor that can probably fit around 10people or slightly more. There are two tables indoor for 2 and a row of bar counter seats. Of course, the tables can be rearranged to accommodate bigger group but you are probably going to have a hard time.

It's a partial self service business. Place your orders at the counters before getting your seat. They will serve the dishes. 

There were three of us and we ordered 5 Pierogis Meal at $20. The portion was sufficient to feed three of us. Ordered the ice tea for $2/each, turned out they were canned ice tea which stated $0.99 on the can. Oh well. 

The food taste was alright. Nothing earth shaking but very edible stuff. 

We really like the outdoor seating especially on a summer evening. It's very comfortable and breezy.

The staff were incredibly friendly which is awesome. They have pretty cute decor too.

Overall a decent dining place to visit for small groups/couples who are looking for a simple fuss free dinner.
author: Cindee T.

description: I was disappointed with the pierogis here. I was looking forward to trying the different flavors and just wasn't happy with the 5 different ones that we had. Maybe they needed more seasoning in them..I don't know. I had to drench them in hot sauce to give them flavor. The side cucumber salad was much better then them which was sad. This place is a dive but I expected the food to be a little better for the reviews that I saw in Yelp. This place is good if you want cheap beer (small selection) and to watch a game. Maybe drunken munchies while you eat with an order of pierogis but not a place to eat while sober. The bartender was nice
author: Lisa H.

description:
I wanted to love this place more than I did. I had been wanting to come here for a while, and then finally made it here, but don't think I'll become a regular of this place. It's located right on 24th and Mission, across from El Farolito, so it's pretty easy to get to via BART or the 14. There's a few tables outside, a few tables inside, and a bar area with stools and 2-3 TVs. Expect a casual meal here and for music to be playing fairly loud (sounds more like a bar than a restaurant) - this probably wouldn't be my pick for a first date since it's a little bit loud and dingy, but fine for a group of 2-4 people (based on the seating available here).

You can choose between the 2 pierogies meal ($10), 3 ($15), or 5 ($20), and each comes with purple slaw, apple sauerkraut, and a salad or soup. There are a lot of different flavors of pierogis, maybe around 10-12 different kinds, including 2 dessert ones (at least as of May 2016). I'm sure the flavors rotate, and there are certainly some unconventional flavors, both for the filling and the dough. If you haven't had a pierogi before, it's like a giant dumpling that is filled with usually potato and cheese and partly steamed / mostly pan-fried. They are not really the healthiest for you, but it's good comfort food on a cold night and pairs well with the sauerkraut and sour cream. They have some interesting flavors like cream cheese & salmon, bacon, potato & cheese, avocado and sausage in a spicy jalapeno dough, spinach and mushroom in a spinach dough. The dessert ones they had were blueberry and a sweet potato one. 

To be honest, the one that I liked was the traditional one, as you can't go wrong with dough, potato and cheese, with fried onions on top. I also got the spicy one with avocado and sausage and thought it was a bit of a weird combo. My boyfriend said this one was his favorite. I also got the spinach and mushroom one but it was a bit bland.

Beers are $5 - they have 5-6 kinds of tap, and bottled beer. The soup they had was borscht, which was a beet soup which was interesting but not a must-have. The cucumber salad was mixed with sour cream and tiny - like smaller than a little scoop of ice cream - maybe the equivalent to 1.5 tablespoons.

We chose to eat inside at the bar to catch the Warriors game, but I don't know where we were sitting had a ton of beer residue from the taps, but there were fruit flies everywhere. In between bites and mid-conversation, we kept on swatting fruit flies away from our food and from trying to take a swim in our beer. My boyfriend said he thought he may have eaten one in the midst of everything. Not to be mean, but I almost felt like I was eating in a trash can with so many things flying around me. 

All in all, if you want pierogis or polish food, this is a good place. It's definitely not one of my favorite places in the city to eat, but I'm glad I tried it. It's fairly inexpensive and pretty filling (actually the food is pretty heavy), but if I went back, I'd get takeout.
author: Christina L.

description: This place is good cheap fun. It's a beer bar with really fresh pirogies, a one man show where everything is made to order and the service is bare bones. The side salads and slaws are authentic.  I'm not that into creamy cheese, so I found the mushroom version to hit the right balance although the potato was good too. My dining buddy got a combo plate and cleaned it in about 5 seconds. Not for vegans but as long as you can eat butter you can find a filling snack here.
author: saru k.

description:
Holy cow I ate here last night and I'm still contentedly rubbing my belly! The pierogis are AMAZING! So fresh and doughy and delicious. I got the original and the buffalo one in the combo plate and gobbled it up! The cabbage slaw was great too and the hot borsht is perfect for a chilly day.
This place is owned by a real ohioan and everyone who works there is sweet and fun! Also I saw a fun comedy and live music show there which only added to the fun atmosphere.
I'll come here again...with stretchier pants!
author: Molly S.

description:
Pretty great food here.  Started off a bowl of borscht which was pretty good as borscht goes.  As for the pierogies, I had the spicy sausage & cheddar, avocado & jalapeno, and the buffalo & blue cheese which were all very tasty.  My girlfriend couldn't stop raving about the chicken & feta, so I'll have to give that one a try next time. The perigois that are labeled as spicy actually are spicy (which is nice to see), and they're pretty big so unless you're starving two of them will probably be enough given the sides they come with.  I think I'd have rather had traditional sauerkraut instead of the sweet apple kraut they served, but that's nitpicking. 

As for the space, it's mostly bar with a couple of tables inside and more tables outside in the covered outside dining area.  Lots of Death Metal being played, and a couple of TV's showing sports.  Decent beer selection too.  Wouldn't go out of my way to come here, but if I happened to find myself in the area I would certially return if I was in the mood for a good filling meal and some beer.
author: Joshua W.

description: Awesome place. Service is super nice! If you are hungry at night, it is definitely a good spot! It is also really really cheap!
author: Sara-Fleur S.

description: Came here after a workout class with a friend and was pleasantly surprised by their pierogies! We ordered a few different flavors to share and the service was quick and friendly. Our server recommended adding a soup to our meal and the borscht was filling and flavorful. By no means is this a high-end restaurant at all, but I wouldn't call it a complete hole in the wall.
author: Ada C.

description: I came here exactly a year ago, and it was my first time eating pierogis, so I thought these were pretty good. But recently I had them at Rich Table, and I was so confused! They were so different, I couldn't believe they were both considered pierogis. I loved the pierogis at Rich Table -- they were one of my favorite items from the tasting menu. The ones here are okay, but not great -- there is no crust, and some of the sides are good but some are just okay. I feel like the different flavors here are good, but they are just distractions (kind of like how a mediocre burger place needs to add sauce and 5 items to make the burger interesting). These pierogis are kind of like warm dumplings with different insides. If this is your first time eating pierogis, you should try them at Rich Table while you can (they change their menu often).
author: Cynthia W.

description:
Pierogies? Yes!

Found Stuffed randomly while browsing Yelp for a casual Thursday night dinner place and spotted the many 5 star reviews. Pierogies? Sure, why not! My friend and I decided to check it out for ourselves.

Stuffed is right next to the 24th St. Mission Bart stop and across the street from El Farolito, which was a very easy commute coming from FiDi. The place was relatively empty when we arrived at 6:30pm so no reservations necessary. There were a couple of tables and plenty of bar seating and you can choose after you order and pay at the cashier.

The menu was straightforward - you can choose between the 2 pierogies meal (~$10), 3 (~$15), or 5 (~$20) and each option comes with two sides. We went with the 3 pierogies meal and added a side of the Polish sausages and dinner came out to ~$20. For our choice of pierogies, we chose the Mushroom, Spicy Avocado (our favorite!), and Bacon Cheddar. Overall, we were very impressed with how flavorful everything was so call us fans!
author: Yolanda C.

description: Great late night joint! These cats are more than chill and will give you the real deal.
author: Joel K.

description: This place is DELICIOUS! Pierogis for the win. And the guy that works there is super cool. This is a hidden gem that makes me the happiest part-polish girl in the world.
author: Kari H.

description:
Cheddar bacon and Smoked Salmon pierogi were the stars of the night when the three of my friends decided to try Polish food. 

We sat in the very back table, completely furnished with cute table-top games to compliment the food.
author: Ryan K.

description:
The food tastes DELICIOUS, different flavors that come together in a very special way! Love it! 

The only thing is that is hard to understand what the restaurant is about, the decor is confusing, the menu doesn't have the description of the food. On Sunday night I saw many people stopping by and trying to understand what was that and most of them just left. It would help having the menu elegantly outside, describing the kind of cuisine, and also a sign that says "open" instead the business hours.

Another big no-no dirty bathroom, is pretty disgusting have a delicious meal and finish with pee smell in you nose :( 

High recommend!!!  Don't let the odd and disconnect decor confuse you, neither the horrible peirogie drawn on the menu hahah
author: Eleonora B.

description:
After a wonderful whirlwind teip to Pittsburgh, I was craving more pierogies, so I searched around to see what SF had to offer, and I found this little gem. 

While the pierogies they make are pretty much nothing like the pierogies I had in Pittsburgh, they are still delicious and the customer service is wonderful. 

The pierogies are HUGE. Easily four times as large as those I experienced elsewhere. The fillings are generous and delicious. I love the classic potato bacon and the spinach goat cheese equally. For ech round of pierogies, they fry the with a huge portion of butter. 

They also have beer, cider, and wine (made by the father) of the owner. 

Top the great food off with long bar and shuffleboard, and you have a great place for an after-drink dinner!
author: Brittany B.

description: A pierogi is a delicious food and everyone should try one (or five). But I really have no idea how to explain what exactly it is - mixed and blended ingredients inside of a wonton that together creates a savory taste? I went with my boyfriend and we ordered 5 pierogis with a side of asparagus salad. Of the five that we ordered, our favorites were the Bacon Cheddar Pierogi and Jalapeno Pierogi, but I don't think you can go wrong with any choice!
author: Emmy Q.

description:
If you're looking for something other than burritos, Stuffed a great place to grab some food next to the 24th Mission Bart Station.

The food here is so tasty and works well as a Pick Up dinner. They usually have a few vegetarian pierogis (I like the goat cheese and spinach one), and the three pierogis order is very filling. They also come with a few incredibly tasty salads.

The space is okay. I probably wouldn't plan to go there for a super special dinner, but I might take a group of friends. In other words, on a scale from Foreign Cinema to El Farolito, it leans towards the latter, but is more expensive. One thing is that I've never had a problem finding a place to sit, but I'm usually grabbing food to go.
If you do want a little nicer atmosphere, but not too pricy, Paprika is right around the corner!

A few things that keep it from 5 stars:
 - It's not 100% consistent: I've had one or two pierogi's that had a lot more dry potato in them. Not very tasty..
 - With the atmosphere and food presentation, I wouldn't go here to impress someone. It's usually pretty empty, but I think a lot of people order food to go.
 - Eh, between the toilet paper on the sidewalk outside, and the sneezing people making the food, and the below 90 health score, I usually feel more grossed out than I'd like to when I eat here.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Unrelated: I found a fabric store shopping bag in my grandma's attic with the address that Stuffed now occupies printed on it. Small world! 

These guys have tasty food. Portions are not huge, but the 2 for $10 combo that comes with a side is reasonably filling (though, keep in mind I have a smaller appetite than, say, an athlete). 

One day I went in and ordered the only two meat-filled pierogis available. The cashier remarked how "everyone seemed to be ordering those two today," so I wonder if the chef leans toward vegetarian menu items or if that was just a random day everyone wanted meat in their pierogis. 

It's nice they have a variety of ingredients but I find I'm usually only drawn to one or two options (my boyfriend feels the same way, but about different flavors, so perhaps this menu-model works for the business). I certainly branch out when they're out of the things I want, or if I'm feeling adventurous, but I can't say I get excited about every option.
author: Krista L.

description:
Fantastic food, great service. I tried them all and i love this spot. The buffalo is probably my favorite, but it is really hard to choose a favorite among all of the great pierogi offerings they give. 

You can't forget the sides either. Every meal gets three sides: Apple sauerkraut, sweet slaw, and your choice of cucumber or bell pepper salads. The bell pepper is my favorite of the two. 

Hungry and eating alone? Get the three pierogi meal and you will be satisfyingly full. You won't feel like you ate a ton of bricks like a lot of bigger portions. It's just perfect. 

I highly recommend checking it out as a pre or post bar food and drink or just a lunch or dinner date for something different than any other joint in San Francisco can offer.
author: Chris B.

description:
I spotted Stuffed while I was waiting for a Lyft near the BART station and it instantly caught my attention. I made it a personal mission to go there ASAP, so I made that happen a few weeks later. 

The employees were awesome. The man we spoke to definitely knew what he was talking about as he described the different pierogies + answered our questions. He even recommended some rad ice cream spots in the area. He was super personable and great to talk to.

I ordered 3 pierogies (comes with a side of cole slaw or sauerkraut), $13 total. 100% worth it. Highly recommend the smoked salmon pierogi. Full of flavor and CREAM CHEESE. Chicken & feta was pretty darn good, too. 

...Now I want a pierogi.
author: Kirsten N.

description:
SO AMAZING!

Okay, back up just a second.  Yes, I'm Polish, and yes, I'm originally from Chicago, so I may have a soft spot in my heart for pierogis as it is.  HOWEVER, if you know anything about either part of that equation, you should know that I can make my own, and I'm super picky about how others make pierogis, so this isn't biased, if anything, it should be considered a testament to how much I loved this place.

It looks more like a bar than a restaurant when you walk in, but there are plenty of seats (both inside and outside), and the staff is very friendly.  I really only wanted to try one (I wasn't too hungry), but when I saw the list of options, I had to try the 3/$10.  I went with the traditional potato and cheese, a bacon cheddar, and a jalapeno one.  They were all served with sour cream and your choice of cucumber salad or some kind of sauerkraut (I believe).  I really wanted applesauce to go with it, but was informed that they've been kicking around the idea of making it.  They make it all in house, so it would add quite a bit of work to the day.

Each one was delicious by itself, and I ate them all because I decided to forego the toppings and sides and focus on the main course.  Absolutely worth being Stuffed.
author: Jes G.

description:
I wanted to love Stuffed, but I really was not too impressed.

For the pierogi virgins, it's a Polish food that looks alot like a steamed potsticker or dumpling, except it's much more doughy and pan fried in a decent amount of butter. The service was so friendly, but incredibly slow, which was particularly inexcusable because the restaurant was at 10% capacity.

2 stars for food quality and speed. The texture and flavor of the mushroom was terrible, even though I love mushrooms! The bacon flavored was the best, but not worth returning for. And worse yet, all 4 pierogi's I tried were cold on the inside. 

They serve wine and beer, but the house red wine tasted more like port, and not in a good way. If you must try it, I would suggest coming during happy hour for the 2 pierogi's + beer for $10 deal.
author: Jess C.

description:
Want a meal under 10 dollars and need some starch? This the place for you. Are these Polish grandma good? Nope. Is this fine dining? Hell No.

What it is a bar with a two burner stove where a sole person pan fries a variety of pierogi, some traditional some out there. Try the 5-pierogi plate and you'll get to try a whole range.

I would have liked more crisp on the outside but the stuffing was filling and yummy.

It simple food, good with a beer or soda.
author: DeathandFood H.

description:
I was back in for dinner on a Sunday night and stuffed cabbage was added to the menu. It was unbelievably good. The pierogies change daily as to their availability and numerous reviews have already stated how good they are. I won't dwell on that. The blueberry dessert pirogi is very good but very rich. Just order one and believe me you'll be full. My girlfriend like the sweet potato pierogies, this is also considered a dessert pirogi.

I spoke with the owner and she had just installed draft beer taps. There are at least 4 types of draft beer available now. While admittedly not a draft beer connoisseur I had a grape fruit flavored IPA beer that was excellent.

The wine selections were excellent, as usual.
This is not fine dining but is great tasting food place  nonetheless.  As far as the price goes you cannot do any better, even in the Mission.
author: Damon S.

description:
I had been waiting in great anticipation for Stuffed to open. I read about all their problems with getting the correct permits, the delays of their opening date, etc. so I have sympathy for them. Opening a new business is never easy and I know there are issues to be worked out. 

I came here on a Sunday and they were offering 5 different pierogis: Bacon & Cheddar, Buffalo, Mushroom & Spinach, Original, and the Salmon & Cream Cheese. We tried one of each and our total was $18, without drinks. We didn't get any beer because none of the beer is on tap and I have bottled beer at home so it's rare for me to want to have bottled beer in a restaurant. 

My favorite pierogi by far was the bacon & cheddar, but this is because it actually had some savory flavor to it. The rest were REALLY lacking some savoriness to actually makes this comfort food comforting. I appreciated the attempt with the buffalo, but it had too much saltiness from the buffalo sauce and the blue cheese--too many strong flavors in one without balance. The others: mushroom, original, and salmon were unfortunately kind of bland. Many of the choices came with some lightly sautéed onions on top of the dumpling. I liked the translucency of the onions, but my boyfriend said it was just as if they were going to caramelize them, but took them out of the pan too early, but I suppose that is a matter of preference. 

Beyond the food not being what I expected, there were some issues I had with the set up of the restaurant. There were some tables outside that had regular chairs, but many of the other tables had stools that were uncomfortably high for the height of the table. If you sat on the stool your knees would ram right into the table top. Not comfortable and it makes for  a messy mealtime. Also, not all the tables had silverware/napkins on them and there was no central area where you would get them for yourself. This just makes it confusing. Is it okay if we take it from a different table? Should we move the whole container of silverware to our table? Confusing. 

Overall, I don't think I'd be back unless they really restructured their menu and added in some more flavorful, savory options.
author: Victoria J.

description:
I have no idea how this place has not been overrun by the hordes of the hungry. I would describe their menu as focused. It's Pierogis, period (although they have kraut, salad, soup, and some sausages). To drink, there is beer. 

There's mostly bar seating, and it does feel like a bar more than a restaurant. There's even shuffleboard. I wish they had vodka, but they don't. Being there made me feel like drinking a fifth of vodka, and I don't even like vodka. 

It's not a place I'd go on a first date, but then I haven't been on a first date in a long time, and even though it's not particularly romantic, it's so pleasantly unpretentious that maybe it wouldn't be a bad idea.
author: Martin W.

description:
This place is great-- the chicken and feta perogi is my favorite. Go with a friend and split the plate of 5. They just got beer taps so even more beers to love. The owner is awesome!

Two big TVs for sports-watching, if that's your thing!
author: Katherine R.

description: All the stars! This is one of those truly special places that you want to share with all of your friends. I wish I made it here more often. Don't miss the borscht.
author: John G.

description:
It's a miracle that this place hasn't yet drawn the crowds that equally awesome Mission food spots normally do. It is also a miracle that I have enough restraint not to come here multiple times a week, since I live around the corner.

The food is so damn good. Buffalo bleu cheese pierogis top my list, but they're all fantastic. The borscht is amazing, though I find that the portion is too small. I've taken various visiting friends here, and it always ends up being a culinary highlight of their time in SF.

One thing, though: I've been several times, and there is almost never more than one person working -- and she always seems sort of stressed out and overworked. No surprise -- she's taking orders, bringing food out, boiling and frying pierogis, making borscht, and who knows what else. Just for the sake of her mental health (and also to decrease wait time a bit), I'd recommend that Stuffed beef up a bit on staffing.
author: Maddie R.

description: Had a potato spinach mushroom and a traditional pierogi with the borscht. I have never had a pierogi and I'm so glad my beau brought me here to try it for the first time. The borscht was comforting...pierogi was perfect (not too heavy). I can't wait to come here again and try all the rest of them...don't forget to put the condiments on the pierogi! It really makes the dish. Atmosphere is relaxed + a hint of dive with some nice outdoor seating. PS two pierogis and borscht are enough for an afternoon snack for two people.
author: Katrina C.

description:
The pierogi were great. My boyfriend said the sausage was delicious (I'm veg). The atmosphere and women who worked there were friendly. The place itself was hospitable and the games in the back made us feel very comfortable.

But. For me, it was all about the borscht.

It was beyond a doubt the best borscht I've ever had in my life. I took home a large container and would have taken home the whole pot if I could have snuck it out without anyone seeing.

We'll be going back again and again.
author: Tanya P.

description:
Today, I checked out this spot near the 24th St BART station.

I got the cheddar and bacon pierogis (two for $10) and it came with a side of sauerkraut. They were pretty tasty and a bit on the delicate side (which is a good thing). And even though I'm generally not a fan of sauerkraut, I really liked this version of it. 

The problem is that for $10, I wasn't really that stuffed (i.e. the portions seemed small) - oh the irony. I think next time, I'd get the original pierogis since they come 3 for $10. I also got a Pacifico to wash it all down but like Maximilliam M., I'm hoping they'll have some taps sometime down the line. The good thing was that the beer was fairly cheap.

I'd say this spot is 3.5 stars but I will round up for now since it is new.
author: Art O.

description: They have shuffleboard too which is always fun. Everyone who works here is friendly and I think the pirogies are great!! There are a lot of different flavors which is fun.
author: Anne K.

description: This place was ok. We were in Chicago where we went to a place called Perogi heaven. I was hoping this place was going to be as good. Nope. Wasn't nearly as good. I hate comparing restaurants, but when you specialize in the same thing, I think it's fair. Food and service were ehh...
author: Chris N.

description:
Story: In house made pierogis with palette stimulating and satisfying sides: Apple sauerkraut and purple cabbage slaw.

Conveniently located near Bart 24th Mission.

Returning value: yes
author: Edward L.

description:
Small neighborhood joint that serves Polish hand made pierogis and beer. I was introduced to pierogis at a Russian friend's house many years ago and love them. They are kinda like potstickers. 

They have indoor and outdoor seating. The food was solid and I recommend sitting outside and people watch.
author: Sunil R.

description: I did not know what a perogie was until I walked into this place. I have eaten every one on the menu and they all are delicious. Highly recommend giving this a try!
author: Aaron E.

description:
I'm of Polish decent so when I read that a pierogi place was coming into the city I knew I needed to check it out.  It's definitely not your traditional pierogi spot but in a good way.  It's more of a bar set up but they did have a table in the back that was perfect for our family.  The staff was really friendly and loved playing with our son during our visit.

We ordered several types of pierogis and my favorites were the smoked salmon (never had that before) and blueberry.  

Delicious and cheap meal!
author: Blake B.

description: Totally overpriced and not special! Those of you who are supposed experts on pierogis should look up the Polish Village Cafe in Hamtramck, MI or Odessa in NYC to see what they SHOULD cost. I've eaten at both many times, my boyfriend is Polish, peirogis are CHEAP PEASANT FOOD and I'm not swallowing this SF hype. Y'all are being ripped off and taking it up the rear, happily. People who say these are fairly priced are not the kind of people I can take seriously.
author: Sally M.

description: This is my first time trying Polish pierogies, and it was amazing. they have many unique flavor, and i really like the spicy avocado & sauage, and blue cheese with buffalo sauce. i can't stop eating them, will definitely go back when I visit San Francisco next time!
author: Cynthia C.

description:
I am a pierogi fanatic. Let's get that out of the way. So when we created a food tour of San Francisco's Mission District during my girlfriend and I's week trip to SF we had to hit up Stuffed. Best part is we totally stumbled upon it.

It's a dive pierogi bar and everything about that makes sense. From the chill ambiance to the cold bottled beer to the perfectly made pierogis and it's accompanying sides - Stuffed is a winner.

Don't go here looking for a gourmet 5 star courses dinner experience, it's more of a grab some friends, grab some brews, grab some pierogis spot. Perfect joint to stop at!
author: Sal D.

description:
Goodness!! How have I not been to stuffed until just this week? It is heavenly.

They serve two things: pierogi and beer. Sides come with the meal. Apple sauerkraut is surprisingly tasty and I usually don't like sauerkraut.

I like the bacon cheddar and mushroom with spinach best. Plain is just plain. The sweet ones are sweet potatoe and blueberry --- they are ok but the savory ones are way more special. 

Staff was incredibly accommodating. But I think they can be a little forgetful. Case in point: they accepted reservations and upon arrival was super happy to put together three tables inside (which by the way is about as much space as there can be; all the rest is bar seating) and did not mind me bringing a 10mo old baby. My baby by the way greatly enjoyed the pierogi! I cut it up to small pieces and they were perfect for her toothless tastebuds.

When later my friends ordered dessert as an add on, the staff forgot about it until we reminded them at the end. So I think the staff are well meaning but you should give them some slack if they forgot some extra orders...after all, it's just pierogi!!! 

The location is excellent, right next to the 24th street Bart. I foresee myself coming back again quite often!
author: Elizabeth T.

description: We ate here for the second time last week. The first time we ate here was about six months ago. That time we were impressed with the food and the service. Last week was terrible. The employee was blasting some kind of music (rap?) Where the words m****r f****r were in every other sentence. I don't need or want to hear someone talking about "doing girls on the hood of my car" as well as other places while I am eating my dinner. I realize that right outside at 24th and mission some citizen was loudly and obnoxiously exercising their right to free speech. I realize the employee was probably trying to drown out the noise from outside. When I asked him to turn down the "music" he smirked at me but did so. Then we had the pleasure of his conversation with a female employee who used either the word f*** or s*** in every sentence. And they could not tell a chicken pierogi from a salmon pierogi. Don't order the polish sausage either. They smother it in american mustard (probably French's brand). I am polish and I don't know one polish person who would do that to a polish sausage. I will never eat here again. This is not a true polish restaurant nor is it suitable for families. And their employees should be ashamed of themselves.
author: Annette M.

description: I grew up with Polish food and while I love it, I totally understand why you don't find more Polish restaurants in this area.  Most items are an acquired taste and are quite different from the sugary preferences most of us have these days.  Despite the very non-traditional fillings in the pierogi, these things hit all the right notes to remind me of my childhood.  The pierogi are comfort food incarnate if you grew up with this kind of cooking in your home.
author: Jeremy K.

description:
3.5 stars. Good and interesting flavor, something new. The service is awesome, super friendly.

Bacon cheddar and smoke salmon pierogis were good. My favorite is the blue cheese buffalo spicy pierogi; it's not that spicy.
author: Happi Y.

description: This place is amazing! We experienced the best customer service here and Dana was the sweetest and took such good care of us, not to mention the food was delicious!
author: Naseem A.

description:
How this place has 4.5 stars, is extremely unclear. We made reservations and arrived Saturday night to only one dude working in the entire restaurant. Thus, we set up our own table (which consisted of chairs of varying heights and comfort), fetched our own glasses, etc. This wasn't a big deal at all, it was just odd how there was literally only one dude working here. And when you make a reservation, you kinda expect there to be a table set up.

For what we then realized was a self-service dive (don't get me wrong- some of my favorite places are dives), it was then odd how it took about an hour to receive our food. You come to a place like this expecting to be in and out quickly - especially when you're not receiving any service / are quenched for thirst due to the lack of clean glasses in the restaurant and the poor dude working doesn't have time to both cook your food and wash the glasses. 

When it finally arrived, the food was good (the cheddar bacon one was our fave) but nothing at all to rave about. Kinda tasted like cafeteria food which was disappointing after waiting for so long.

I have no complaints about the dude working there - for being the only person there, he held down the place pretty well. But the food was unmemorable and the service-excruciatingly slow. In my opinion, there are much better places to be trying in the Mission.
author: Rachel L.

description: This meal is giving me life! Right balance of veggies and protein. Not to mentioned sweet hospitality.
author: April P.

description: Tried a few different pierogis here, all of which were pretty good.  The best one was the bacon cheddar one.  A few of the ones we tried had wrappers made out of some interesting types of dough, but the standard dough had the best consistency.  The apple sauerkraut was also really good.  Overall, good food at a reasonable price.
author: Simon L.

description:
Did I ever mention that I was convinced I was part Polish when I was younger? Well, you can't ever go wrong with pierogis in my book, especially when you have so much variety. 

Between my boyfriend & myself, we tried almost every pierogi they offered. I'm a huge fan of the mushroom, bacon-cheddar and avocado-sausage ones. The smoked salmon was tasty if you like salmon, but I'm not sure if I'm a fan of it in pierogi form. If you have a sweet tooth, you MUST try the blueberry dessert pierogi too.

The only downside is that you can't just order a ton of pierogis. Instead you have to buy portions in 2 or 3 or 5 pierogi combos. Each combo comes sauerkraut (delicious), cole slaw (mmm mmm) & a choice of one of two salads (not a huge fan of either). However, I wish they would just allow me to order any number of pierogis, without a combo meal. What if I just wanted 10 pierogis? That's what I'm talking about!
author: Anna R.

description: Excellent! The food was so good. A mix of traditional pierogies and some fun new flavors. The service was amazing and it had such a fun atmosphere
author: Brooke S.

description: I walked right by this place on my hunt for food near 24th St. BART station -- I'm glad I circled back. This is probably the epitome of comfort food for me -- warm, doughy, unpretentious so you don't worry that you're eating it wrong. The pierogi were satisfying and distinctive, the sides were actually delicious. It's hard in SF to get traditional cooking that tastes like someone made it with love. Most food tastes like someone made it to impress you. This is the love version.
author: James L.

description:
This place makes me sad that I moved away from San Francisco! I'd go here all the time if I lived here.

I tried:
goat cheese and spinach- awesome!
Jalepeno cheddar- also delicious!
Buffalo and bleu cheese- good, though mostly tastes like hot sauce 
Spicy Avocado and sausage- good.

And the sweet potato dessert pierogi- good but overly sweet, but I'm not that into sweets.

Looking forward to coming back on my next trip
author: L B.

description:
A gem in a sea of overpriced, underwhelming Mission restaurants. We had a delicious fun lunch: avocado and sausage pierogi, goat cheese and spinach pierogi, awesome sauerkraut and side salads. I had a $1 high life: you couldn't have picked a better option for me for a beer choice. And the owners listen to metal, hells to the yeah.
Locals should be excited to have this homey, original, absolutely delicious, extremely affordable restaurant in the hood.
author: Priya R.

description: Wow. What a little gem. Spicy avocado and bacon cheese were my favs. She serves her dad's wine and it's tasty -- I liked the "Gravel," a Cabernet - Merlot blend. There are also board games and shuffle board in the back.
author: Ted M.

description:
It's time I reviewed this place because I live right around the corner and have been her about 5 times already. I like to support local businesses; not because I feel sorry for them, but because they make great food and treat you like family and I do think it helps their business to Yelp it.

I read the negative reviews for this place, and ask you to consider the people who wrote them. Have they been to the restaurant multiple times? Did they have preconceived notions about what they wanted? Do they seem like someone you would want to share a table with or are generally help, well-adjusted individuals? I think I have an idea for my next screenplay. 

Now to the food *not for thought*. I came here without knowing what a pierogi was, and was foolishly expecting a filling and meat-heavy piroshki-like experience. So I avoided it for a while, and of course I was wrong. These babies are light and not too greasy, yet they absorb alcohol well (for your hangovers). The flavors range from very powerful (the buffalo, which is too powerful for me) to very subtle (I like the goat cheese the best). Avocado and mushroom are both good choices. I haven't tried the bacon one yet, as I don't eat very much pork. In the end, I think all of them are pretty good and just different enough to keep you coming back for more.

My favorite part is the the various toppings included with your meal. Both the asparagus and cucumber salads are really light and refreshing, mixing wonderfully with the flavor of any pierogi. The hummus and sour cream are fun. And, ooh! look! there is wonderful sauerkraut and sweet red cabbage finely chopped! They really tie it all together and make it so fun to eat. That's what Stuffed brings to the table; it's casual, lighthearted and hearty without being disgustingly filling. I actually don't feel that 'stuffed' if I just order 2 pierogis and call it a day. 

As the neighborhood improves I think this place has the potential to become an institution. The owners, Andy and Dana, are there every night serving you personally with heart and soul. You get to watch them make the food right in front of you. Dana's dad bottles the wine. No techie vibe here. They are improving their menu and evolving, and I'm just so thankful to have something besides pizza and burritos to eat while I sit and drink my beer and watch the Nature Channel with my girlfriend on one of their two huge TV's. Hey, you guys, keep up the great work!
author: Chris j.

description:
My mouth is still watering from the memory of the cheddar bacon pierogi. Everything we tried was so delicious and comes with tasty little sides. 

This place is a rare find. For those looking for a glitzy mission experience with table service at the snap of your finger- it's not the place for you. 

If you are looking for sinking your teeth into an authentic pierogi. Go here. 

The owners are super sweet, generally only 1-2 people working cooking up fresh batches at your call. Always a tiny wait for food/ service but worth it.  

It's the place my east coast friends say- it's just like home. Glad they found a home in SF.
author: chri l.

description: This was my first time trying pierogis, and boy, were they good. Who knew dumplings could pack so much flavor and deliciousness inside of them? I want to go back and try all of the ones I didn't get to have (unfortunately, I'm not from SF, so it may be a while). Until then, I'll just have to leave this very satisfied review.
author: Shannon C.

description: The Pierogi's here smell like they came from mothers Verna's kitchen. They are served with some great TLC by Dana and Dwayne like they never left the home land. Stuffed is what's up!
author: Dillon M.

description:
Great food, great service.

Kind of reminds me a bit of empanadas rather than typical pierogies (they 're bigger). Super tasty though. The owner is super nice which is great. Affordable beer and wine prices and the food is well priced too. Highly recommend this place! Not your run of the mill restaurant so if you're looking for something different in the Mission def stop in here
author: Dee K.

description: I absolutely adore this place! Andy and Dana are the friendliest hosts, and so down-to-earth and sweet! The perogis are simply delicious! I love the texture of the dough and the fillings are all excellent! I especially love the Salmon (amazing with the cucumber and dill salad) and the jalapeño! I also love the asparagus salad and the coleslaw made with apples! Plus, Dana's dad supplies his homemade red wine from Oregon. I wish I could buy it by the bottle! Such a chill, unpretentious place with quality, homemade comfort food. Excellent location (across from 24th St. BART) makes it the perfect place to grab a bite before a night out (or on the way home). Great neighborhood joint where the owners remember you and treat you like family. Also love watching them cook right behind the bar counter seating. I always leave feeling stuffed and happy!
author: Tamara S.

description:
My partner and I went to Stuffed early in the afternoon for a pre-dinner snack of home made pierogies and found them to be authentic and creative as well as delicious. After a sit down dinner and a wonderful dance concert at ODC, we had a hankering for something else and made an instant decision to return to Stuffed for a meal with the sides. The owner/manager, Dana, is a friendly and charismatic woman who stood outside with us and talked about her background and how she and her partner came to create Stuffed. When we left we told her we would recommend her place highly to our friends so please go! She and her partner have been working very LONG days for over a year and if business picks up a bit they can hire another worker to ease the load.

Highly recommended!
author: Gregory N.

description:
Polish pierogi,so yummy!!! Huge portions and so affordable. Great place to have a meal like your mother would prepare. I loved the spinach and the cheese pierogis. The soup of the day or the borscht was very delicious. The restaurant is easily accessible by the Bart or several bus lines. 14,49,48.
Dana, who is the owner is extremely friendly and full of great energy. She makes you feel welcome. I highly recommend it!
author: Heda B.

description:
I'm Polish, I've been to Poland and half my family is Polish. Needless to say I've had my fair share of Polish food including many Pierogis. Hell, I can even make a mean Pierogi myself. 

That said, these are amazing! Nice twist on the traditional, very tasty with a great price! And the best part is they list soda on the menu as Pop! That combined with all the drug deals and homeless people out front I felt as if I was transported back to Hamtramck.

This is a must try! Hurry before they get crazy busy!!
author: Jeff C.

description:
Gotta say that the Pierogis lived up to the hype. I am quite inexperienced with regards to eastern european cuisine, so I didn't really know what to expect when my friend described them as 'dumplings, but eastern european'. Having only heard that in an Asian context, I didn't really know what to expect. 

What came was a terrific spicy avocado sausage pierogi, which was actually quite aptly described by that statement. Sandwiched within a dumpling-esque exterior lay a heavenly cheesy mixture. I became an instant fan.

As for the sides, the cabbage slaw is great. I'd probably pass on the cucumber salad and get the soup instead for the combo. Even though I've never tried Borscht before (soon to be back for it!), it has to be a better deal than the tiny bit of cucumber salad that was placed on the plate.
author: Alexander L.

description: Had 3 pierogis (potato and cheese) for $13.  Comes with 2 sides; I had borscht and apple sauerkraut.  All were delicious, but borscht was lukewarm.  The bartender/waiter didn't appear to be fully engaged, but obviously was, since he got everything right.  Interesting, low-key place.  Uncrowded around 6 PM on a Friday.
author: Phil H.

description: Awesome, tasted like a little piece of home. The ambiance, the service and the company was great, I will definitely come back for more. Thank you!!! From Poland with love.
author: Aleksandra F.

description:
legit pierogi in SF. FINALLY. it warms a polish girl's heart.

newly opened so they're still working out the kinks, but the space is nice, the service is friendly, and the pierogi are delicious. looking forward to trying it again once they've worked out the typical new restaurant issues. smacznego!
author: Sarah B.

description:
So, while I'm sober.

This was opening night, and they had friends helping out and a massive crowd and apparently their folks out hovering around and being parents. 

I came in around 7:30. Two comfortable wooden stools in front of the bar counter. Two Olympia beers, two orders of two perogies. They were running low on a few types because it was toward the end of the grand opening, so they gave us three orders of three different kinds of perogies and they offered another round of Olympias. 

So, was I happy splitting six fairly enormous perogies and finding one had bacon and potatoes in it? Obviously I was, that's a ridiculous question. Don't even pretend like it would make you upset to eat a bacon and potato perogi. It would be like your birthday. Anyways, It was good perogies, like the kind your friend from Milwaukee or Chicago would have to resentfully admit was 'yeah, that's pretty good.'

And they all seem like really nice and friendly people, but mostly, I really enjoyed eating those perogies.

If you like perogies, this is a place that for a relatively small sum of money, will give it to you so you can put in your face-hole. Or, you can eat it like a civilized person. It's up to you. It's just perogies, and they're good, so you should be happy, because now you have a place where you can go and do that.
author: Sergi A.

description:
I came across 'Stuffed' unexpectedly. Initially I went on a bit like this to my husband: 'oh my God, pierogi in San Francisco at last. I'm going to get deliveries every Friday, forget Mission Chinese etc.' 

And then, I sat down and ate. Ok, so maybe it was their off day, maybe the usual cook was on vacation or some other disaster hit. Because it wasn't good. Dough was so thick that it seemed hard in places, filling - I had the mushroom ones - wasn't particularly flavorsome. I don't think I have ever been so disappointed in my whole life. You could say that I cried in my pierogi. 

The truth is I am very passionate about pierogi - this is my first Yelp review ever - and I am hoping they can improve. Good luck. And two stars for trying.

I'll review again in a month or two.
author: Zuzanna P.

description: Great location!  Being of eastern european decent and from Chicago I know what a pierogi is.  My wife and I stopped in for dinner and each had the three pierogi meal.  We tried a bunch of different pierogi, buffalo, bacon cheddar, spinach, goat cheese and enjoyed them all.  Each meal is also served with sauerkraut, your choice of cucumber or bell pepper salad and sweet red cabbage salad.  Everything was delicious.  in addition they have a nice selection of beers from cheap to fancy.  Can't go wrong with $3 for High Life tall boys.  Can't wait to go back!
author: Nick G.

description:
During my first trip ever to San Francisco last week, my boyfriend and I were wandering around the Mission when this place caught our eye. So glad we decided to stop in!

This place is amazing.  This is a real pierogi! The dough is perfectly crafted with a variety of choices from traditional to salmon to buffalo. You truly can not go wrong. 

They have a decent beer selection which is expanding in the very near future according to the owners who were working during our visit.

The owners were awesome and made our experience that much better. My only wish is this place was in San Diego so I could eat here every day!!
author: Jaimie B.

description:
Really enjoyed this place.  It's casual, the owners are super nice and great food.  I've never had a pierogis before so came in with an open mind.  Delicious.  They use seasonal ingredients to make the sides and salads too.    

What was also refreshing are the prices which are very reasonable.  I will for sure be back!
author: Jessie W.

description: A cute place that is really convenient if you're meeting a friend for dinner who's coming in on the BART! The staff is really friendly and they make all their own pierogis.
